I'm a big Scott Foley fan and went into this hoping that I'd like it. Who wants your favorite star to put out a movie you really hate? Anyway, I have to say that I really enjoyed it. It's definitely not for everyone. I couldn't have watched it with my grandmother.

I loved it so much more the 2nd time because there are so many subtle comments and facial expressions that I missed the first viewing. There are so many moments where you think, "Did they just say/do that?!?" and the answer is yes. They did. And it was freaking hilarious.

The cast was great and included many of Scott Foley's friends and family. Patrick Wilson stole the show with his expressions and ability to spit out an unexpected line with the straightest of faces. His wife, Dagmara Domiczyk, was amazing as Ward's wife, Stacy. Outrageously funny in her portrayal of the bitchy wife.

The characters are so unlikable that you can't help but like them, or at least love that you hate them. It even has a happy ending. What more can you want?

This is a movie worth buying, so you can watch it as many times as you want to.

One reviewer wrote it's difficult to explain black comedy. Well, has that reviewer or any other viewer considered the irony underlying  the story's series of events from which rises its humor?  Comedy of this movie is rooted in the irony of the predicament and how the characters respond to that predicament. Hilarious moments occur many times in this movie.

Directed by Scott Foley is better known for his acting in TV shows, The Unit and Scandal. Lets Kill Wards Wife comically portrays how a group of four friends, suburban professionals, conspire to get away with murder. The event of the killing itself is incidental, not premeditated. Or is it?

A premise such as this is the set-up in which the comedic action takes place. Besides this movie being a comedy, it is also a buddy movie. Through the situation brought on by the murder of Amanda, Wards wife, the story demonstrates an examination of how this specific murder affects the relationships between the four guys. How the situation of the murder is set up makes it so even wives of two characters, Tom and David, become quickly involved. Even the wives are neither horrified by what has transpired nor unwilling to participate in events connected to the murder's cover-up.

 As a group there is very little remorse demonstrated by anyone. Instead the groups behavior would be better fitting in the event of their killing, feather plucking, and then carving up a fresh chicken. Its the groups displayed nonchalance in this ghastly situation that makes this film humorous.

As said, shocking series of appalling events connected with the murder and its cover-up fail to elicit any semblance of horror in or among the characters except in one character, Ronnie. His sense of remorse occurs in sharp contrast to each character's matter of fact sense of banality about the murder.

That demonstrated effect of banality in the outrageous context of the murder and its cover-up is at the root of what makes this film a comedy. Perhaps that is the intent of the screenwriter, to dramatize another aspect of the banality of evil. Such banality ironically invites the viewer to identify with the characters.

If you're a fan of black comedies like I am, then Let's Kill Ward's Wife will be one of the funniest movies you've seen. While some may feel the acting is a little forced and characters a bit too on-the-nose, especially in the case of the titular wife, it all fits perfectly to create a truly entertaining comedy about broken marriages, golf, and the various ways to dispose of a human body.

The film has a rather talented cast with the likes of Patrick Wilson and Donald Faison playing an out-of-work actor and the hapless husband of the worst wife in the world respectively. Wilson's matter-of-fact way of getting through the grizzly process of disposing of a murdered woman's remains produces many of the laughs, and Faison really makes you feel sorry for this truly broken man whose soul has been stamped into the dirt by his detestable spouse. While the titular wife (whose name and actress elude me) is practically cartoonish in her behavior, you still manage to hate the ever-loving heck out of her and eagerly await the inevitable to finally happen. Toss in the fact that Ward's neighbor is a cop, played by the always lovable Greg Grunberg, and you have a pretty intense and hilarious film with plenty of laughs.

It's pretty clear that when Ward dipped his wick, you truly committed a mahor blunder.  He was roped into marrying a very abusive woman, and it's clear that her death would be a blessing for Ward - all his friends agree.  One of them, in fact, even suggests that they figure out how to kill her.  Was he kidding?  He says so, unconvincingly.

But they don't murder her, exactly.  When she abuses one of Ward's friends, he erupts into action, shoving her face into food - but when she extricates herself, she falls, and apparently the crack on her skull kills her.

Afraid that the friend will be convicted of manslaughter, the friends try to figure out how to make her disappear and never be found, and THAT is the gist of the movie.  It works well as an "elevator pitch" for making the movie, I suppose, but this isn't the first recent "OMG, how do we deal with a corpse" movie; in fact, the most notorious even had a sequel.  And it's not like the gag is running thin on this third movie; it ran out of gas halfway through the first one.

There's a place for this kind of movie.  At the drive-in "passion pit" theatre, nobody much watches the movie much anyhow.  But usually, those movies have a lot of nearly-nekkid bodies to put sexy thoughts in young heads, and a chainsaw-wielding villain so she can jump upon his lap and demand to be held tightly, and she can pretend she's afraid and not admit she wants to be well and thoroughly, uh, "romanced."  The games we play, all because we pretend that "decent" young women don't have human urges!

Lacking those stereotypical drive-in scenes, it becomes difficult to figure out who should see this movie.  The  actors and the director seem to not be at fault - but the screenwriters deserve a bonis for this movie, not because the script is so great, but because it's amazing they did this well, considering the constraints.  The Geneva Conventions should prohibit abusing writers this way.

My newest adventure into Hollywood has me watching Let's Kill Ward's Wife. Going in, I've heard that this is a quote "black comedy", but honestly... there isn't anything that this movie has in common with any black comedy that I've ever seen. The movie's plot involves a group of close friends with Ward, a new father who has quite possibly the worst wife in any movie that I've ever seen. She makes jokes about rolling ontop of her baby and makes it a point to be miserable and angry, especially at her husband Ward. I wish I were kidding, but even the wives of the friends say the same things as their husbands.

As Ward's wife is finally murdered, it becomes an involving plot in disposing of the body. This is pretty much the WHOLE plot, from the murder which happens not so long into the movie. So it really isn't that long of a film, thank goodness! But even from the start, looking at the description, I knew it wasn't going to be great. But I DID think it was going to be interesting to watch. I was not disappointed in this, but there are infinitely better movies out there. In the end, if you want to watch a movie that is subpar and not overly terrible, then you will want to look at this.
